notes.text: In the sentence I will do whatever you ask of me (in which whatever = anything), whatever is correctly spelled as one word. But in the interrogative sense (what ever was Mary thinking?), the emphasis is on ever, and it should be spelled as the two words what ever because ever is serving as an intensifier to the pronoun what. See also however and wherever

definitions: used to emphasize a lack of restriction in referring to any thing or amount, no matter what
shortDefinitions: used to emphasize lack of restriction

examples.text: you have our support, whatever you decide
whatever decision he made I would support it

notes.text: In the sentence I will do whatever you ask of me (in which whatever = anything), whatever is correctly spelled as one word. But in the interrogative sense (what ever was Mary thinking?), the emphasis is on ever, and it should be spelled as the two words what ever because ever is serving as an intensifier to the pronoun what. See also however and wherever

definitions: used for emphasis instead of “what” in questions, typically expressing surprise or confusion
shortDefinitions: used for emphasis instead of 'what' in questions

notes.text: In the sentence I will do whatever you ask of me (in which whatever = anything), whatever is correctly spelled as one word. But in the interrogative sense (what ever was Mary thinking?), the emphasis is on ever, and it should be spelled as the two words what ever because ever is serving as an intensifier to the pronoun what. See also however and wherever

definitions: at all; of any kind (used for emphasis)

examples.text: we told him we'd back him whatever

notes.text: In the sentence I will do whatever you ask of me (in which whatever = anything), whatever is correctly spelled as one word. But in the interrogative sense (what ever was Mary thinking?), the emphasis is on ever, and it should be spelled as the two words what ever because ever is serving as an intensifier to the pronoun what. See also however and wherever

definitions: said as a response indicating a reluctance to discuss something, implying indifference, skepticism, or exasperation

examples.text: Joseph's commentary amounted to “Yeah, well. Whatever.”

shortDefinitions: said as response indicating reluctance to discuss something, often implying indifference
